question: A 2 kg ball is moving to the right at 5 m/s when it is struck by a bat, causing the ball to move to the left at 10 m/s. What is the magnitude of the impulse delivered by the bat to the ball?
solution: Impulse is equal to the change in momentum of an object. Initial momentum is p_i = mv_i = (2 kg)(5 m/s) = 10 kg⋅m/s to the right. Final momentum is p_f = mv_f = (2 kg)(-10 m/s) = -20 kg⋅m/s (negative sign indicates direction to the left). The change in momentum is Δp = p_f - p_i = (-20 kg⋅m/s) - (10 kg⋅m/s) = -30 kg⋅m/s. The negative sign indicates the impulse is to the left. The magnitude of the impulse is |Δp| = 30 kg⋅m/s.
